In Julia, Write a pig latin transformer called `pig_latinify` that operates on a vector of strings. It iterates over each string and changes it to pig latin. Each iteration should run on a separate thread.

Here's an example of how you can achieve this in Julia using the Threads library:

```julia
using Threads

function pig_latinify(words::Vector{String})
    results = Vector{String}(undef, length(words))
    
    @threads for i in eachindex(words)
        word = words[i]
        if islowercase(word[1])
            results[i] = "$(word[2:end])$word[1]" * "ay"
        else
            results[i] = "$(word[2:end])$word[1]" * "Ay"
        end
    end
    
    return results
end
```
This function `pig_latinify` takes a vector of strings as input and returns a new vector where each string has been transformed into pig latin. 

The `@threads` macro is used to parallelize the for loop, meaning it will execute multiple iterations in separate threads simultaneously. 

Within this function, we perform a check to see if the first letter of the word is lowercase or uppercase and adjust accordingly. We then append "ay" (or "Ay") to the end of the word, moving all letters after the first one to the front. 

The new vector of transformed words is then returned from the function.
